title: How to Make Gift Bags from Reused Copy Paper Packages

steps.headline: Take the copy paper out of the packaging.
steps.description: Do so without making any tears in the packaging, taking a little extra care to open the packaging at its glued spots. Try to keep one end of the packaging firmly secured by the original glue.

steps.headline: Turn the packaging into a bag.
steps.description: Glue the side of the bag back together. If both ends of the packaging were opened, glue one back in place, using the folds originally made by the manufacturer (hopefully, this won't need to be done).

steps.headline: Fold the flap on the remaining open end of the packaging inward.
steps.description: Secure each side of this end with glue, tape or staples.

steps.headline: Decide on the handle length.
steps.description: Measure out and cut the ribbon pieces to exactly the same length for both sides of the bag.

steps.headline: Punch holes into the bag.
steps.description: Punch four holes on the top of the bag, two on each side, using a hole puncher. Be sure to align them exactly opposite each other, in a position that will allow for tying the handles in place.

steps.headline: Make the handle for the first side.
steps.description: Insert a piece of ribbon or any other material that can go through the hole in one hole. Tie a firm knot on the inside of the bag to secure it. Repeat for the other hole on the same side, ensuring that there is plenty of handle for holding, then knot on the inside to secure as well.

steps.headline: Repeat for the holes on the other side of the bag.
Decide whether or not you'd like to decorate the bag.
steps.description: The bag can be covered with decoupage from magazine cut-outs, copy paper with a design you've hand drawn on, or any other easy-to-find (and preferably scrap) pieces of paper. Glue in place. If adding a design, draw this on before gluing in place, as it's easier that way.

steps.headline: Consider ahead of making this bag whether you'd prefer a plain white bag.
steps.description: If so, you can undo the whole copy paper packaging and reverse the above process to only show the white insides as the outer part of the bag. This requires finessing the folds, however, as you'll need to reverse fold the base of the bag following the lines already made by the manufacturer. When folding these in the reverse way, do so firmly and cleanly, to ensure that they stay in the new direction you're folding them in. Be sure to glue and tape the base in place firmly, so that the contents won't fall out. Once done, this can be decorated by gluing on pretty things such as artificial flowers, sticker rhinestones (form a name or word), stickers, pompoms, scrap fabric, and any other craft or decorative items you'd think would work well.

text: Forming the bag Take the copy paper out of the packaging. Do so without making any tears in the packaging, taking a little extra care to open the packaging at its glued spots. Try to keep one end of the packaging firmly secured by the original glue. Turn the packaging into a bag. Glue the side of the bag back together. If both ends of the packaging were opened, glue one back in place, using the folds originally made by the manufacturer (hopefully, this won't need to be done). Fold the flap on the remaining open end of the packaging inward. Secure each side of this end with glue, tape or staples. Adding the bag handles Decide on the handle length. Measure out and cut the ribbon pieces to exactly the same length for both sides of the bag. Punch holes into the bag. Punch four holes on the top of the bag, two on each side, using a hole puncher. Be sure to align them exactly opposite each other, in a position that will allow for tying the handles in place. Make the handle for the first side. Insert a piece of ribbon or any other material that can go through the hole in one hole. Tie a firm knot on the inside of the bag to secure it. Repeat for the other hole on the same side, ensuring that there is plenty of handle for holding, then knot on the inside to secure as well. Repeat for the holes on the other side of the bag.  Decorating the bag Decide whether or not you'd like to decorate the bag. The bag can be covered with decoupage from magazine cut-outs, copy paper with a design you've hand drawn on, or any other easy-to-find (and preferably scrap) pieces of paper. Glue in place. If adding a design, draw this on before gluing in place, as it's easier that way. Consider ahead of making this bag whether you'd prefer a plain white bag. If so, you can undo the whole copy paper packaging and reverse the above process to only show the white insides as the outer part of the bag. This requires finessing the folds, however, as you'll need to reverse fold the base of the bag following the lines already made by the manufacturer. When folding these in the reverse way, do so firmly and cleanly, to ensure that they stay in the new direction you're folding them in. Be sure to glue and tape the base in place firmly, so that the contents won't fall out. Once done, this can be decorated by gluing on pretty things such as artificial flowers, sticker rhinestones (form a name or word), stickers, pompoms, scrap fabric, and any other craft or decorative items you'd think would work well.
